head.citation-title: Quaternion wavelet magnitude/phase and multi-scale local binary pattern representation for face recognition
head.abstracts: This paper proposes a novel face recognition method based on the Quaternion Wavelet Transform (QWT) magnitude/phase and the multi-scale Local Binary Pattern (LBP) representation of the face images. This recent QWT is a near shift-invariant tight frame representation whose coefficients support a magnitude and three phases. These quaternion magnitude and phases are combined and extracted different scales LBP features. In this approach, a face image is modeled as a "histogram equalization sequence" by concatenating the histogram equalization of all the QWT magnitude/phase multi-scale LBP parts. For recognition, Chi-square distance is used to measure the similarity of different "QWT multi-scale LBP histogram equalization sequences" and the nearest neighborhood is exploited for final classification. The proposed approach is evaluated on the standard September 1996 FERET large-gallery image sets. Significant improvement in performance is observed. Compared with Gabor wavelet features, QWT magnitude/phase features are superior both on accuracy and computational complexity when the same classifier is used. Although EBGM has better rank-1 recognition rate in the probe set Fb, the proposed method is superior on other three probe sets. Moreover, the proposed method has few free parameters to adjust and has much lower computation complexity. Â© 2011 Binary Information Press December, 2011.
